title: Camila Pacheco Ria√±o, PhD
text: I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôve found your way to my webpage. As an ecologist who specializes in biogeography, I‚Äôm passionate about understanding how living things are distributed across the planet and the factors that shape those patterns. Thank you for stopping by!

title: About me
text:
I am a global change ecologist and biogeographer, currently working in the EDGE LAB at Department of Biological & Environmental Sciences at University of Gothenburg.
My research focuses on understanding what drives the complex patterns of biodiversity change over time in mountain regions around the world.
I grew up in Colombia, surrounded by stunning landscapes and diverse ecosystems, which sparked my passion for ecology. At the same time, I witnessed the very real threats of climate change and human activities on biodiversity, experiences that shaped my drive to understand the patterns and processes behind these changes.
As a computational ecologist, I use analytical tools and Bayesian modeling to create innovative frameworks that help answer key ecological questions. My work focuses on analyzing big data and uncovering the global processes that influence biodiversity‚Äôs distribution across space and time. While much of my research has centered on the Neotropics, I‚Äôve also explored Forest, Alpine, Tundra, and Mediterranean ecosystems.
In addition to my research, I‚Äôm deeply passionate about data visualization and making science accessible to a wider audience, especially when it comes to wildlife conservation.
My research activity is structured around five main lines:

Funded positions
Any funded positions will be advertised on Jobbnorge, on the EECRG webpage and on twitter etc.

Visitors
Visitors are welcome for a research visit.

Interns
Some projects have paid internship positions, often for fieldwork during the summer.

title: Get in touch!üì¨
text:
Project ideas
If you have project ideas and think I could be a great collaborator or supervisor, feel free to get in touch vie email. Let‚Äôs chat!

Doctoral level courses

Forthcoming
Living Norway Open Science Training ‚ÄúResearch Course on Open, Reproducible and Transparent Science in Ecology‚Äù, Hjerkinn, Norway 13‚Äì18 November 2023


Recent

Living Norway Open Science Training ‚ÄúOpen, Reproducible, and Transparent Science in Ecology‚Äù, team member, Finse, Norway, 2022
R for palaeoecologists, Course Leader, University of Cape Town, 2019
Plant functional traits course, Team member, UNIS, Svalbard, 2018
Plant functional traits course, Team member, Chengdu, China, 2015

Master level courses

University of Bergen
I am the course leader for three 5 ECTS Master‚Äôs level courses.

Bio300B ‚Äì Biostatistics
Bio302 ‚Äì Biological data analysis II

Bio303 ‚Äì Ordination and gradient analysis

I also make contributions to

Bio250 ‚Äì Palaeoecology. I teach the section on dating and age depth models.

Rklubben
I host a weekly peer-learning drop-in session for R code (and statistical) problems (Fridays 1400-1600 in Tunet).

Teaching resources

Together with Dr Aud Halbritter, Dr Jonathan Soul√© and others, I wrote Enough R to write a thesis. This is a collection of interactive workbooks and shiny apps to teach the use of R, quarto for reproducible documents, git and GitHub for version control, and R package development.
These workbooks are used to support regular and special courses.

title: Research
text:
EDGE LAB



PPF-Alpine aims to take a deep dive into the biogeographical history of alpine systems on a global scale and decipher the drivers of present-day alpine biodiversity.



Ecology Group Unibasel

Past projects

PalaeoDrivers
PalaeoDrivers was an NFR funded project to develop methods to test the significance of quantitative palaeoenvironmental reconstructions.
Role: PI


The Matrix
The Matrix was an NFR-funded collaboration with Makerere University, Uganda, to explore biodiversity in the fragmented tropical forests and the surrounding agricultural matrix.
Role: Co-PI


FunCaB
FunCab was an NFR funded project to investigate the role of Functional group interactions in mediating climate change impacts on the Carbon dynamics and Biodiversity of alpine ecosystems using the Vestland climate grid.
Role: Partner

title: Popular Science & Outreach
text:
Contributions to iNaturalist

Contributions to TidyTuesday: #TidyTuesday is a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem and the {tidyverse} package bundle to wrangle, explore and visualize the datasets.
‚Üí All my contributions
Can Plants ‚ÄúMove‚Äù Fast Enough to Escape Climate Change?  Here you can find the kids paper FYM 






Mismatch between the temperature to which the plants are adapted (Past) and the new temperatures due to climate change (Present)





How will the climate be in Norway in 2100?  We found that 82.5% of the mountain areas in Norway currently above the forest line will grow forest. This means fewer alpine areas (if the forest keeps pace with climate change, it will probably lag). This projection was base on the RCP 4.5 pathway for the period 2071-2100. Here you can find the interactive website NRK








2013
2100










Different shades of green: different forest types in Mountains.Dark grey:alpine areas
